[2818.1s - 2829.1s]: Beautiful. Beautiful. But I'm struck that, and I want to ask you in a minute about this wonderful phrase agnostic pantheist. But let's hold that thought.

[2919.9s - 2941.3s]: Let me at the outset state that I'm a huge believer in the positive potential of capitalism. I think it's been an incredibly positive force in the last couple of hundred years, certainly here in the United States and bringing out the creativity of the world.

[2959.7s - 2977.4s]: and someone named Raj Sosodia, who happens to be the Whole Foods endowed professor at Babson College, where I previously was president, developed this concept of conscious capitalism.

[2977.4s - 3007.4s]: And it can be explained very simply. There are three tenants. In the United States, in the past, the legal concept of a publicly owned corporation has been that the greatest response, where the owner, you respond, is really legally of the management and boards of those country companies has been to maximize shareholder's.

[3007.4s - 3019.8s]: And this is led to some unfortunate practices in the field of capitalism.

[3019.8s - 3036.9s]: Conscious capitalism, by contrast, posits that the only responsibility of management is to be driven by their purpose and their mission.

[3037.7s - 3056.5s]: In the case of Whole Foods Market, that purpose and mission was to sell the highest quality, natural organic, delicious, healthy foods possible, and help change the way people eat for the better and help change the way agriculture is practiced for the better.

[3056.5s - 3070.6s]: So pillar number one is to be driven, company should be driven primarily by their purpose and mission, not by profit, not necessarily by profit, of maximization. I'll say a word about profits later.

[3070.6s - 3094.1s]: Secondly, pillar is that these organizations should be led by what I call servant leaders whose job it is to create a culture that's going to bring out the best in everybody associated with the enterprise, not the command and control on the smartest guy in the world, do it my way type of leadership.

[3094.1s - 3110.2s]: The third and most important thing is that companies should be focused on optimizing the returns to all their stakeholders, not just one stakeholder, their investors.

[3110.2s - 3138.6s]: And by when I talk about their stakeholders, in the case of Whole Foods number one was the customer as a stakeholder, number two, the team member or employees as stakeholders, number three partners in the supply chain, in the case of Whole Foods that met the farmers and the middlemen in the process.

[3139.9s - 3152.1s]: So yes, of producing the food that they sold. Number four investors, yes, they're important, but it's the whole idea is to optimize the return.

[3152.1s - 3170.8s]: Number five, as a stakeholder are the communities in which these companies operate and with a thoughtful consideration of making sure there are positives returns to those communities.

[3170.8s - 3184.4s]: Number six is the environment that corporations should follow environmentally responsible approaches and do their best in that regard.

[3211.8s - 3223.7s]: Initially it was in partnership with Mohammed Yunus who developed the concept of this type of language.

[3326.6s - 3337.5s]: He had been born in Germany and he gave sermons in both German and English every Sunday.

[3411.8s - 3421.7s]: And I see this positive force every place, particularly when I look in nature.

[3550.2s - 3561.0s]: Sure. It's from Damien, Herman Hesse. Every man is more than just himself. He also represents a unique,

I absolutely delight in how much you share in the book about love and your love for your

I've been a lucky man.
What I'm struck that you've also been a mentor and advisor to so many folks in business,

What is education?

I've been giving a lot of thought to that whole concept of education.
I'm struck by the fact that we have in the United States and really in the world at

Something that starts in preschool or kindergarten and ends with a degree.
It could be a high school degree, it could be a college degree or some sort, even an advanced
degree.
And then that ends our formal education.
And I think we are living at a time when we've got to change that concept of education.
We have to become lifelong learners.
If one thinks about it, the world we're living in today is changing more rapidly than it
has ever been the case in the past.
Particularly with the advent of the whole STEM or STEAM area, science, technology, engineering,
the arts and mathematics.
And it's just knowledge is exploding exponentially.
Every two years we're generating an amount of information equivalent to all of the information

And it's Moore's Law applied to education.
It's a life extraordinary.

I think it's a really important set of topics.
One of those themes is that developed initially by Clayton Christiansson and Professor

And in this book, I argue that higher education is probably going to be the next major target

Professor Christiansson talks about the reason for that of being the explosion of that STEM area

And I think that which is led to the development of what are called MOOCs massively online,
